Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Integrating DNA and Inorganic Surfaces for Functional Materials Design

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) grant is to develop a fundamental understanding of the structure and properties of DNA-functionalized surfaces and to formulate rules that will facilitate the design of new functional materials for biosensors and enhance our ability to control and direct the materials assembly processes. Surfaces functionalized with DNA are used for biosensing or for the self-assembly of biological, organic and inorganic moieties. DNA density and structure on the surface, choice of surface material and curvature, and type of surface immobilization can significantly influence the properties of DNA-functionalized surface and the behavior of DNA-based material assembly. This study will utilize molecular modeling techniques to formulate a theoretical description of the correlation between DNA structure, surface design and properties of DNA-functionalized surfaces.

If successful, the research will facilitate progress in materials for DNA microarrays and biosensors, DNA based targeted drug delivery, DNA nanomaterials assembly, and DNA directed surface assembly and patterning. The proposed research program will be closely integrated with the educational activities and will provide new education opportunities in disciplines related to DNA and functional surfaces for high school, graduate and undergraduate students. The results from this research will be integrated into a new course addressing nanoscale simulations and modeling. This project includes an outreach module on materials design for high and middle school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this NSF project was to develop a fundamental understanding of the structure and properties of DNA-surface interactions and to formulate rules that will facilitate the design of new functional materials for biosensors. We utilized molecular dynamics simulations to formulate a theoretical description of the correlation between DNA structure, surface design and properties of DNA-functionalized surfaces. Overall, our studies discovered that modifications of surfaces chemistry can control the structure and dynamics of ssDNA and provided a comprehensive picture of the phenomena occurring at the interfaces between biomolecules and the surfaces. Our study provided (1) the design rules for tuning of organic / inorganic surfaces that can pave the way towards the development of many novel applications using biopolymer – surface complex, (2) the insight into the conformational changes of ssDNA structure with different lengths or its network morphology by calculating the persistence length, aggregation number, number of hydrophobic cores, and percentage of bridge chains in the network, and (3) the guidance for a better choice of surface chemistry and solvent for the surface functionalization to make substrates more stable.  The results from this proposal can potentially be used for the supports of the future development of new materials and will facilitate progress in DNA microarrays and biosensors, DNA based targeted drug delivery, DNA nanomaterials assembly, and DNA directed surface assembly and patterning. The novel DNA-based biosensors and targeted drug delivery will lead to the development of new diagnostic and therapeutic approaches to human disease. The results have been published in peer-review journals, presented at the conferences and reported by public media. The NSF funded CAREER award has resulted in the training of 3 graduate students, who have earned their doctoral degrees, and 9 undergraduate students. All students were participating in early outreach activities and public presentations.  The results from this research were incorporated into a new course on nanoscale simulations and modeling.
